The success story behind all this effect is the fact that due to the shaft encircling the person holding the inner end of the shaft, the rotating mass particles in the plane of the static wheel are not moving in a flat plane but the masses in the upper half are moving in a thick volume where the masses are causing a centrifugal force into the upper half of the disc. This has nothing to do with the conventional centrifugal force which is radial to the wheel. The masses on the lower half of the wheel have centrifugal force moving out of the lower half wheel and so the wheel is torqued against the falling weight, If one plots the motion of one particle moving along with the wheel, one can see these other two centrifugal forces almost parallel with the shaft acting on the upper and lower face. There is a side component to cause the wheel gyrate around the person holding it.
The down ward torque , that is weight gravity multiplied by length of shaft is balanced by the two horizontal forces acting on the upper and lower halves of the rotating disc acting at a distance from each other.

Exactly how the Hammer of Thor works, it is.

STEP 1.
Increase the speed of rotation around the body.
The gyroscope begin to rise due to the gyroscopic effect.
The arm feels the full weight of the gyroscope, but remains motionless.
The axis of the gyroscope tilts.

STEP 2.
Decreases the speed of rotation around the body.
The gyroscope begins a slight falling motion.
Immediately lift the gyroscope rod, which is no longer heavy, until it becomes horizontal.
The two steps are resumed.

From these combined movements results the SUBJECTIVE feeling that less mechanical work has been done to lift the gyroscope. In reality, the mechanical work is the same, but forces with other orientations come into play.

When it's a dead weight your hand, wrist, arm, shoulder, torso, etc. has to control all 6 degrees of freedom. When the weight is spinning the 2 rotational DOF in the plane of the disk get prescribed. Rotation towards the ground, is very slow (let's just say it's locked out) and the precession is a constant rate. The only rotational DOF you have to control is the spin axis of the disk, the easiest direction for your wrist and forearm muscles to control. It's noticeably easier for you to lift the weight when it has 4 DOF than when it has 6.

SOLVED... sort of.
The distance it would take to move the disc straight up is much less than the distance that it travels as it spirals around. Therefore, when the disc is spinning it seems to act like a lever or pulley... spreading the force required to move it up out over a much longer distance. So it would feel much lighter as it spiraled up because you have to exert much less force at any one moment... but of course you would have to exert the force for much longer to move it up the same distance.
How is the spinning disc acting like a lever or pulley and doing this with the force? I don't know. Have to think about it a bit more. But it is no more antigravity than a guy pulling up an engine block with a pulley or a man pushing a massive truck up a very gentle incline.

I analyzed this situation rather deeply and this is how it goes.
1. When the wheel spins, and the held shaft does not drop nor goes around the operator, then the acceleration of the flat spinning mass particles remains flat in a plane, as in the case of centrifugal forces.
2. When the wheel is allowed to drop vertically, the spinning sets in a horizontal velocity component on the shaft to cause it to rotate almost horizontally around the central person. This, in turn, causes the one-way spinning particles on the upper half to have a different velocity ( in magnitude and direction) from those on the lower half, hence the original flat accelerations will become three dimensional, where the three-dimensional accelerations on the upper half of the spinning wheel will produce a force inwards towards the man in the centre and the three-dimensional accelerations on the lower half will produce a force outward from the man in the centre. The inward forces on the upper half and the outward forces on the lower half of the spinning and translating wheel working in cooperation with the length of the shaft will produce torques to balance out the dropping weight of the " three-dimensionally" spinning, translating wheel. where each spin is not in a flat plane as when the wheel is held and not dropping.

Actually, the explanation for it to feel weightless is easy. You are using a leverage to raise the whole thing. It's easy to raise your tip of the pipe, because it's light. The other tip, the heavy one, is raising itself, because it has to stay perpendicular and is spending some kinetic energy while pulling itself up to stay perpendicular. And the total weight of you and the wheel doesn't change, when you are raising it, because of this energy being spent by the wheel. If it was not turning and you would just raise the wheel (maybe with two arms, to make it easier for you) you would actually be a lot heavier during all the time you are raising it, since as you push it up, you are pushed down by the wheel. The fact that you don't weight a lot more while you are raising it is the proof that there is another energy being spent to raise the wheel. And that is the kinetic energy of the wheel turning a little slower as you tipp your end of the pipe up and the wheel has to pull itself up to stay perpendicular.

A bit of the “give-away” to the non-intuitive nature of what’s going on occurs when he attempts to stop the bar from waving around.
I.e. he’s moving the bar around his body. Then notice that when he attempts to stop the shaft from rotating (horizontally) around his body he needs to grab the shaft with the other hand and turn his body to help reduce the horizontal motion of the shaft.
That is, he doesn’t simply stop the horizontal motion of the shaft.
(In other words the gyroscopic effect is producing a pseudo-force that is perpendicular to the “expected” motion of the axis of rotation).

I don't think it was made clear here that the "variation in weight" was a false perception by the holder.

When only the big, strong muscles are engaged, the perception of weight is less than when smaller muscles are also engaged.

Using the smaller muscles makes them "complain" more, giving you the false impression that the thing is heavier, but when its just the big muscles, you get the immediate impression that it got lighter in weight.

It is about time the real explanation was given in sequence, here goes. Later I will give my own version of what is precession, but lets, for now, assume that people know what "precession" means.
Consider the wheel in the video which is spinning clockwise with respect to the drill, and looking plan view, then the extension arm is rotating clockwise.

1. As the spinning wheel is released, the weight of the wheel drops down with the hand being held at the same level. This will tilt the spinning wheel about a horizontal diameter. THIS DROP WILL CAUSE THE FIRST PRECESSION ACTION in a horizontal manner
2. During the drop/hence wheel tilt, considering the two spinning mass particles on the vertical diameter of the spinning wheel, the upper mass accelerates out while the lower mass accelerates in with respect to the pivot support arm. This acceleration results in the spinning wheel reorienting its spinning plane by 90 degrees, such that the hand tends to be shifted clockwise horizontally with respect to the spinning wheel. Since the hand is fixed, it is the spinning wheel that takes this horizontal reaction and accelerates to move clockwise to gain an angular velocity a little more than Wp, precession horizontal angular velocity of the extended arm.
3. As the horizontal extended arm accelerates fast and reaches a little more than Wp ( the natural precession rate) then the masses at the end of a horizontal diameter of the spinning wheel will accelerate in and out, and so 90 degrees later the spinning wheel reorientates itself such that it will apply a heavy vertical load on the supporting hand. This will take the added load reaction to lift the wheel up to the original level before it dropped down in the first place. THIS IS A SECOND PRECESSION EFFECT EXACTLY AS THE FIRST ONE but oriented at 90 degrees with it. Two added 90 degrees equal 180-degree rotation and so the original drop action, after two precessions, will become a lifting action.
4. Lifting the wheel to its original level will slow down the precession angular velocity below Wp and so the lifting will stop and the spinning wheel will then drop again to repeat the action. It may be regarded as a high-speed oscillatory action between a vertical drop in potential energy, with the wheel gaining a horizontal angular velocity around the pivot, then this Kinetic energy is used to lift up the total weight of the spinning mass to the original level. All done through two lossless precession actions, first one horizontally and the second one vertically up. The high-speed rate at which this takes place may be looked at being a continuous action, except in a nutation process.

The definition of precession. Take one case. When the spinning masses of a gyro wheel are also rotated around in a circle on an extended arm, (as in the video) then the followed trajectory of one spinning mass particle acting on the wheel, is a three dimensional (nonflat) cycloidal path which causes the creation of different " arching" accelerations at different locations, hence the creation OF TWO varying CENTRIFUGAL FORCES, one acting in an inbound direction on the upper half of the spinning wheel, and the other in an outbound direction acting on the lower half of the spinning wheel. These two equal centrifugal forces cause a vertical torque to tilt the plane of the spinning wheel where this resulting vertical torque will change the orientation of the spinning plane by 90 degrees. Note that in this case since the two opposite acting centrifugal forces acting on the upper and lower halves of the spinning wheel are equal, then the experiment shown in the video will result that there is no resulting centrifugal force on that spinning and continuously precessing wheel around an extended arm.
If an extension arm is not used, but the gyro is torqued, a similar reaction will follow.

So, a torqued gyro spinning wheel will produce two equal opposite varying centrifugal forces, acting on different halves of the plane of a spinning wheel to produce a reorientation at 90 degrees to the original torque action.

That wheel is a gyro. it wants to stabilize its position. Lifting it non-spinning actually takes the same force as while it is spinning (follow the spiraling direction otherwise it takes even more effort to lift it!). But, there are radial forces pulling that wheel into its position so it takes less effort to keep it steady. This is the only thing what happens. The spinning flywheel would actually fall down to earth with the same speed as if it would not spin. It would fall by doing a spiral of course while it is spinning because of the precession forces. I just tell friends that the real problem has nothing to do with weight! As you explained in the video, the problem is holding the bar horizontal - almost impossible when the flywheel is not spinning. It's the gyroscopic action of the flywheel that holds the bar horizontal. Gyros resist any attempt to change the angle at which it's spinning.
And then our problem is explaining gyros to others. Newton's laws of motion are all we need, and recognising that fast objects can't be pushed aside - they just change direction of motion. And as for using angular momentum vectors to say WHY it happens... arghh! I just say "Maths is useful for quantifying things that happen, but not necessarily explaining why they happen".

The gravity wheel is by far the best demonstration of what gravity is. Yet mankind still hasn't figured it out! Gravity is an emergent phenomenon. It is spacetime (ST) contraction caused by the SPEED of mass. Fundamentally it works opposite to the vector of movement of fast objects, or (in case of a spinning object) orthogonal to the plain of spin. A gyroscope suspended in weightless space best illustrates this:
https://youtu.be/xQb-N486mA4. In this video, by holding the spinning wheel on one end, earth's gravity is trying to change the wheel's axis but the gravity wheel's 'artificial' directional gravity opposes this change of direction, just like the gyroscope in space does. What's there not to understand? What about restmass you may ask? same thing!. Here we have subatomic particles spiraling around the nuclei of atoms, producing similar directional orthogonal ST mini contractions. It is only because all orbits are and atom are utterly unaligned that the collective contraction (Restmass gravity) APPEARS to work radial. Einstein's GR thus is not fundamental, but just a mathematical approximation of how atoms collectively contract ST. I hope humanity finally understands and stops acting as if gravity is something mysterious and unexplainable....

if you let out on a spinning rope, it is under less tension as you release it, just like if it were falling.  That tiny bit of slack you give the rope gives it a tiny bit of outward momentum.  If the system tightens back up, that momentum can either come to a dead stop, or be transferred in a new direction.  It's that simple.  Hooking a cord to it is the problem.  But now we have wireless energy transfer.

Professor Eric Laithwaite. MagLev train inventor. Rejected by the Royal Society on his gyro theory. In his 1974 lectures, Laithwaite suggested that Newton's laws of motion could not account for the behaviour of gyroscopes and Laithwaite suggested that they could be used as a means of reactionless propulsion[3]. The members of the Royal Institution rejected his ideas and his lectures were not published at the time, a first for the Royal Institution.

Had Laithwaite sped up his ball and stick wheel to the point where
a balancing weight was no longer needed, he would have observed the following:
The top weights bend towards the tower.
The bottom weights bend away from the tower.
This bending arises from the back spin giving a differential travel speed to
the top and bottom line of weights, cf. the effect of back spin on a cricket ball.

Thus the top weights rotate around the tower at a lower speed than the bottom weights.
This induces a couple, or moment to use the structural engineering term more
familiar to me, acting on the gyro.
This couple is the pair of centrifugal and centripetal forces holding up the
gyro as it orbits the tower.

What about centrifugal force? Surely this should pull the gyro away from
the tower since the end of its axle is simply resting on a shallow depression on
the top of the tower.

Looking down from the top of the gyro the it will be seen that the top line of weights

is convex towards the the tower whereas the bottom line is concave.
Thus there are two centres of curvature for the path of the weights on either side of
the gyro orbit.
Far from being no centrifugal force there are two.
These act in opposite directions and virtually cancel each other out.

I know why the gyro is easier to lift. Individually, the angular and linear momentum are NOT conserved separately. This is a mistake in physics. The SUM of angular and linear momentum IS conserved, however, AND this correction to (or clarification of) Newton's Rule by Laithwaite allows for the conversion of one into the other.
In your experiment, just as in Laithwaite's experiment, the gyro was easier to lift while it was spinning, even though the weight didn't change. If your scale had a platform which could rotate as you stand on it, you would find that the gyro naturally wants to precess and your whole body would precess with it. This represents the almost complete conversion of the downward component of its initial fall into MORE angular momentum. When you lift it, the gyro rotor dips even more downward causing an increase in the processional angular momentum. Thus, the SUM of the two types of momentum (linear and angular) is conserved, even though one got smaller and the other got larger.
The reason it is easy to lift is that the upward momentum you give it with your hand is mostly converted into angular momentum. This causes the force of lifting to virtually disappear. It is a real effect. Any upward momentum you give it is going to show up in downward momentum and register as a force on the scale, or a weight increase. Physics is not perfect. It contains a few glaring mistakes like this one. Keep using your brain. It's working fine.

This is super simple and no, it’s not how flying saucers would fly if they existed.

Centrifugal force. When the disc is spinning really fast, they centrifugal force is almost as strong as gravity which explains why our skinny host can suddenly hold the stick with the spinning disc at one end.

The trick ONLY works when the spinning disc is held vertically because gravity pulls towards the mass generating it while the centrifugal force pulls equally in all directions away from the axis of the spinning disc. If he had held the stick with the disc straight over his head, the trick would fail as the centrifugal force was pulling to the sides instead of downwards.

A flying saucer would therefore need to be vertical instead of horizontal and even then, the centrifugal force would only help carry the discs, not make them or anything else weightless. And that doesn’t even address the energy needed to spin such discs fast enough to ALMOST nullify their own weight.

Just think about it.

Deducting 6 miles from 30, the distance from the horizon to Holyhead, on the one hand, and to Dublin Bay on the other, would be 24 miles. The square of 24, multiplied by 8 inches, shows a declination of 384 feet. The altitude of the lights in Poolbeg Lighthouse is 68 feet; and of the red light on Holyhead Pier, 44 feet. Misleading video. At 02:40 we can see the dude giving the axle a push with his left hand while lifting the axle upwards with his right hand. By doing this he creates an orbit, the flywheel moves up and reaches it's highest position above his head. If you look carefully you can see the descent of the flywheel starting right after it reached the highest point. The flywheel drawes it's orbit in the air. It's impossible for the dude to hold the flywheel in the air, just because the flywheel wants to continue its orbit. This video has nothing to do with magic, one just have to understand whats going on when we're talking about the momentum of inertia.

@Veritasium Weight lifter here. You're not crazy. The wheel should have felt lighter when you lifted it while it was spinning. Due to the gyroscopic effect, your body didn't need to waste energy stabling the object while lifting it. It's the same reason it's easier to bench press a 200lb barbell than it is to bench press two 100lb dumbbells even though you are technically lifting the same amount of weight. The stability of the object being lifted makes a big difference.

THE PRECESSION HAS NOTHING TO DO WITH THE WEIGHTLESSNESS BUT IS PURELY DUE TO FRICTION IN THE BEARINGS ALLOWING THE DISC TO PUSH THE SHAFT ROUND AS SHOWN FROM 2:29 to 2:40 WHERE NO PRECESSION OCCURS.
BUT FROM 2:41 YOU ARE INPUTTING FORCE/MOVEMENT INTO THE SHAFT WHICH MAKES THE BEARINGS CONTACT THE DISC AND THAT REACTS BY PRECESSING.

When the gyro is raised above the head = for a short while the disc is only making very light point contact with the bearings and so it is practically weightless and can be easily lifted. A horizontal gyro canno do that as gravity is pushing the disc down onto the bearings constantly regardless of gravity.

It's indisputable the shaft and gyro weigh the 40pounds.
It's indisputable that it cannot really be lifted with one extended hand.
It's indisputable that it can easily be spun up over the head quite easily for a very brief time.
It's indisputable that after about one circle above the head the weight once again becomes fully 40pounds.
Therefore the spinning gyro for a brief time does appear to lose weight.
It might be that the precession of moving the shaft causes instant and unrecognised stiffening Newtonian reactions in the skeleton and muscles.
However the ease that the gyro can initially be raised above the head might actually be a demonstration of anti-gravity at a very restricted gyro speed/precession combination that only exists for a very short time - less than one circle of the head?
Consider this: At a certain specific rpm the gyro bearings have very little load when the disk is vertical with shaft horizontal.
The disk will be trying to fly out in 360 degrees in effect taking almost all contact off the bearings but for a very tiny spot contact with each ball or roller in the bearing - or if a plain bearing is used there will be a minimum thickness oil film of practically zero friction.
As the disk is experiencing 360 centrifugal force at full speed it will have little friction and all its weight is pulling away from the shaft in full 360 degrees and in effect be weightless and have anti-gravity!
As the speed drops below the critical point the centrifugal force will drop and the disc will begin applying heavy vertical friction on the bearings thanks to Newton's apple!
As the weight increases and the disc speed reduces as the circle above the head slows the precession and increased friction will come into effect to make the weight once again appear and make it impossible to hold the shaft horizontally or raise it above the head until the disc is once again spun to maximum speed.

Add some sort of external directable power such as air jets or magnets and maybe the action of the power on the fuselage might induce some precession in the disc that might enable the UFO to lift off. Logically fine adjustments of the power would allow take off, slowing and steering?
We know Earth acts like a big magnet and logically some drive could be made to take advantage of this for use in a UFO that is weightless while its gyro disc is spinning superfast.
Introduce Nikola and his multiplying coils to create a gyro with an immensely fast speed and zero friction thanks to magnetic bearing and power source for a UFO is feasible.

As I commented on https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t34Gv39ypRo & the original Laithwaite video some years ago, the orthopedics, bio-mechanics, and kinesthesia of holding the gyroscope are critical to the perceived ease of lifting the 'live' vs the off-balance 'dead' weight. Lightweight's(;-) perceived difference in ease of the lift is just that (a difference in perception). The 'dead' weight must be lifted out of balance, but the 'live' weight can be lifted at a point, as close to his body CoG as convenient so he can lift straight up against the live load, vs out & up required for the dead load.
Davidowski's re-enactment would have been just as valid, and more convincing (like yours) if he had used a fish scale and an engine hoist to more closely reproduce and improve the objectivity of his predecessor's not-quite-clever-enough understanding of a clever demonstration of body mechanics.
Pretty well done, but you could have improved your understanding or Laithwaite's original folly if you had worked with a sports or physical therapist or someone more familiar with the bio-mechanics of this experiment, who could have better explained the surprising difference in difficulty in lifting the two systems. I noticed in the video, that it looks easier to keep the lifting point over your feet for the 'live' load, than the 'dead' load, and that the 'live' load is more stable than the 'dead' load. You actually take advantage of the precession by lifting it with your right hand. I suspect it would be somewhat more difficult with your left hand, unless you reversed the spin of the weight and therefore the precession.
BTW1: Consistent with common sense (and a dumbbell), slightly more while you lift, the same while it is moving horizontally behind you, and slightly less while you finish the swing back down in front of you.
BTW2: This is related to the 'magic bracelet' sales scam where the salesperson 'tests' your strength without and with the magic bracelet, by pushing straight down on your extended arm without the bracelet or drink (or whatever 'health' trash he is selling) and then slightly toward your feet with the product, making it seem you have suddenly become much stronger.

I hate to remind you, but Professor Sir Eric Laithwaite wrecked his career with the same demonstration at the Royal Institution Christmas lectures in the 1970s. What he didn't take into account, and which earned him the ridicule of physicists, is that the lifting force is no more linear than the motion of the flywheel. Precession converts a rotatory force in one plane to an acceleration in a plane perpendicular to the force. The lifting force on your wheel is tangential to its position, rotating the axle around the fulcrum at its opposite end - i.e. you.
Sorry, you can't use gyroscopic precession to create flying machines or reaction-less drives. If you pair two flywheels and rotate their common axle you don't get a linear resultant force, you get two forces that cancel out if the axle is rigid or bend the axle at its centre if it's flexible. Gyroscopes are great for navigation though.

The reason the spinning weight feels lighter is all down to your ability to grip a stable weight versus a loose weight trying to roll and torque out of your hands. You can see a good real life example of this in the carnival scam games where you're challenged to hang from a bar for two minutes. A fit person can do this, if the bar is fixed. In the carnival scam, the bar is on rollers which twists the bar out of your grip. When the weight is spinning, it's like a fixed bar as opposed to a loose rolling bar. Much much easier to hold.

Hi to everyone.
I think I have explanation for the propulsion effects that so many people report online. Let me try to explain.

Look at this video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GeyDf4ooPdo

The reason why it is easier to lift the gyro wile spinning is because it has no inertia. The weight of the gyro is still the same it just has no inertia when he is lifting it wile precessing. That is why it feels lighter...he does not fight against the inertia. You can see this when he is on a scale in the next video. When he lifts the gyro wile standing on a scale the needle of the scale wobbles around one weight, it only massively changes at the end when he returned the gyro down...BUT without a precession, he just put it down. That way it has inertia and it showed on the scale.It is on this video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tLMpdBjA2SU&

So the reason why it feels lighter is only by the fact that the person who lifts the gyroscope doesn't fight against the inertia, it just lifts the weight. If you try to lift the gyro without precession it will feel as heavy as when it is not rotating. Are we clear on that?

Please look at my device:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L3U9BH_al_A

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xZP_ZbnGA9I&t=20s

This is my centrifugal (precession) propulsion drive. Here is my theory behind it. Gyroscopic precession has no moment of inertia. You can find that in relevant articles about gyroscopes, it is a science fact. This means that when you rotate my device and the arms of the device start to go forward due to precession, this movement forward of the arms has no moment of inertia, or the whole apparatus does not have opposite moment of inertia...This is very important. Now when you stop rotating the gyroscopes (motors at the end of the arms of the device) the precession stops and the centrifugal force returns the arms back. This movement BACK is not induced by precession so it has moment of inertia. This means that arms move in one direction without inertia. The trick is this movement back of the arms to be stopped by precession so it cancels the reaction (third newton law) and you have forward movement. So the movement of the arms in one direction is caused by precession and in the other direction is caused by the power of the centrifugal force, then they are stopped by precession and the cycle repeats itself. This is why the moment of inertia is unilateral. You do not brake the third Newton law. There is not a problem with the physics in it. Simply the movement forward of the arms is caused by the precession of the gyroscopes (the arms) and has no moment of inertia (does not cause reaction) and when you stop the rotation of the arms the precession stops and now this movement of the arms (caused by centrifugal force) has moment of inertia. This way when going forward, the arms of the apparatus does not have moment of inertia and when the gyroscopes are turned off and precession has stopped the centrifugal force returns them back they have a moment of inertia. That is why the whole apparatus will be moving forward. The problem with this device is however that the gyroscopes on the arms are to small and produce small precession

HOWEVER YOU MUST UNDERSTAND THE MOST IMPORTANT THING!
The most important thing is that the precession must stop with precession. What this means. Imagine you re in space, weightless and no air around you. Your arms are spread and you flap them once as a bird and stop. Will you move? No you will not. Why? Because the movement of the arms DOWN will cause opposite reaction by the Newtons law, and when you stop your arms this force will be equal and in the opposite direction so you will not move at all.
Now this is why the movement of the arm must be stopped by precession.
When you rotate the device the arms go forward due to precession and this movement is without inertia. When you stop the gyroscopes rotating action the precesson stops and the arms go back due to centrifugal force. But if you don't stop this movement by another precession (start the rotation of the arms) the force will cancel itself (same as that astronaut). But when you stop the back motion of the arms (caused by the cetrifugal force only) the inertia is cancelled by precession. In this case the astronaut an move forward. That is why you get a forward motion.

Well i have a hypothesis, since the wheel is spinning very fast then the weight is being flung outwards from the axis. Causing a kind of high pressure gravitational force on the edge of the wheel, this would be created via inertial drag, now granted the amount its minuscule. However since this is happening at edge that means the center of gravity for the wheel would in a sense expand and decrease the spacial density, in essence creating a low pressure zone along the axis of the handle. Basically since the centripetal force is at play the high rate of spin would cause a slight gravitaional imbalance, as inertia drags the air around it in an effort to slow down the mass, it causes high and low pressures in both the surrounding atmosphere and the gravitational potential controlled by the deflected air molecules.

What I would like to see is this: What happens when the rate of the angular velocity at which you are spinning is increased beyond the natural rate of precession but the bar connected to the 40 pound wheel is always held horizontal (you don't allow it to rise) ... that is, you don't lift the bar over your head but just hold it horizontally there at waist level while you force the velocity of precession to exceed the natural rate of precession. What happens to the weight of the entire system then? Because I'm thinking the weight of the system as measured by the scale will decrease under those conditions due to the fact that the spinning wheel will want to rise, But it can't because you're using the weight of the system to hold it down.

Stated another way ... Here's an example of the kind of test I'd like to see: You need to be standing on a surface that can freely spin as you hold the 40 pound gyroscope. This spinning surface is placed on top of the scale so the entire weight can be measured (just as you did in the video ... except now we have the additional weight of the freely spinning surface you're standing on). Record the weight of everything (you, the 40 pound fly wheel and connecting bar, and the freely spinning surface you're standing on ... everything that's on top of the scale). Now rev up the 40 pound gyroscopic wheel to high rpm. This starts the surface you're standing on to begin rotating at the natural speed of precession. Now one other thing is needed. We need to be able to increase the angular velocity of the spinning surface you're standing on so that you spin at a greater velocity than the natural precession speed. Doing this would make the 40 pound gyroscopic wheel want to rise. But you don't let it rise. And additionally, you keep the pipe that's connected to the 40 pound spinning gyroscopic wheel horizontal ... it's not allowed to rise at all. So under that operation ... what weight is the scale reading now? I think it will be less than the dead weight of the system as previously measured. Additionally, I think there's an angular velocity above the natural speed of precession which will result in the system levitating. So I think I agree with Eric Laithwaite (there is something here that everybody has previously missed). And if I'm wrong I'd love for you to prove me wrong by actual demonstration using the scenario I've just outlined .

Boeing wanted to use a flywheel APU in the tail on the 787 to replace the centrifugal jet APU. It was a good way to reduce tons of aircraft weight maintenance and fuel burn. Now I realize it would be practical but a flywheel APU would have torn the tail structure apart on every take off landing or turn. Aircraft structure are design to a minimum 1.5x load and to hold on to that flywheel APU would have added a ton of weight to the tail just to hold the flywheel APU in place.  At first I thought it was due to possible damage if the composite flywheel broke up but that is only one issue the other issue is the gyroscopic precession effect

Just to clear the term 'anti-gravity' up, in science fiction, the concept of "anti-gravity" requires no energy input - it is a natural physical state (like the opposite poles of a magnetic field) (though that may be a bad example, since magnetism itself requires energy input, and it can degrade over time without further energy input as the source matter changes).

Here, the spinning wheel is merely "temporarily working against" gravity, requiring energy input (provided by the drill) to initiate it, and a constant input of energy to maintain it (which this spinning flywheel doesn't get - so it slows down and gravity overcomes it again, until the drill speeds it up again). If you include 'working against gravity' in the term 'anti-gravity', then the drill can be classified as an 'anti-gravity generator'. So this 'anti-gravity' is not 'anti-gravity' proper ('proper' meaning the commonly held notion/definition of it), but merely working against gravity, as when you jump in the air or propel yourself into space. If you include 'work' in the definition of 'anti-gravity', then your legs and rocket engines would also be classified as anti-gravity generators (as would anything causing movement against the force of gravity).

the gravity will always try to change the angular momentum if the supporting force does not go though the object's mass centre. so when you don't rotate it, the added angular momentum is perpendicular to both the rod and gravity, so the rod will have to rotate around your wrist(because the AM is already added), making the rod seem like falling. but when it starts rotating, the added angular momentum is exerted on the already existed one, making its orientation to change. so the gravity actually only does the very exact same thing, which is to add angular momentum to the thing, but the effect is different.

so what was the answer?

The wheels indeed appears weightless when held in that way. It's a perceptual illusion well understood in terms of Gibson's theory of perception (J.J. Gibson). It's actually the handle that appears to carry all the weight at the point where it is being held. The way the wheel itself would normally appear to weigh is evaluated by the perceptual system through the torque on the handle required to hold it up(which is indeed huge when the wheel isn't spinning, as shown early in the video). However, when the wheel is spinning, this torque is being cancelled, hence the appearance that the weight is displaced close to the location where the handle is held (and, indeed, the downward force is displaced there) and the wheel itself at the other end appears to be weightless. The perceptual system is tricked due to the abnormal and unfamiliar conditions.

So basically, what your hand cannot afford is not the "weight" of this stuff (as shown in 2:00), but the "torque" (Imagine that you hold the small end and lift this hammer, "unnatural" right?). Let me put in this way, "To do a handstand is far more easier than doing a human flag", now you know what I mean.
OK, so the physics is, at the end of the day, you still have to be capable of lifting stuff as heavy as this hammer, BUT! The ridiculous "torque" in X-axis caused by the gravity can be totally cancelled by the "Z-axis spin of an Y-axis spinning object."
Technically, The Y-axis spinning object has the "angular momentum" in Y-axis, and the spin in Z-axis make this angular momentum change in X direction thus having torque in X direction.
If my XYZ is not clear:
Z: to the sky
Y: the direction where the rod points at
X: the direction perpandicular to where the rod points at

Conclusion: It's inaccurate to say "anti-gravity", so you cannot build an UFO in this way (I know you are thinking stuff like this aren't you :D)

Hope you enjoy the Physics !

What happens: the rotation wants to stay in a specific orientation. Upon being forced to rotate downward, the torque results in a different force. This is also the result, mathematically, of cross multiplying vectors. Two rotations added together results in a rotation that is 90 degrees apart from both other rotations, in this case to the guy's right, and clockwise. Same thing works with a bike wheel supported by a rope. It will still fall, just way slower. To those asking why it cannot help with lifting payloads: the work is still being done. The work of spinning the wheel is slowly dissipated as the wheel loses kinetic energy. A good example you can try at home would be a pinwheel/fan. Attach a string to one end of the rod, and a wheel to the other. Letting go without rotation results in it just falling. Spinning it will make it spin like you see in this video. Now, replace the string with your fingers. When it's not spinning, it's very easy to change the direction it is facing. Spin it again, and try to change where it is pointing. The resistance you feel is what is holding that wheel up. Without rotating it, try lifting it up, down, left, and right. If there is no rotation, you should experience no resistance. That is why these cannot be used for rockets, or lightening payloads or hovercraft. Hope I helped!

Equal. There is no anti-gravity effect at all. It's a gyroscope, and all the weight is still there, so he is lifting all its weight, (19 kg). In a gyroscope there isn't a force directed upwards, there is rather a resistance to tilting downwards of the part of the axis of rotation where there is the wheel, so all the weight of the wheel is transferred to the pivot, (the hand in this case).
If you make spin a gyroscope on a scale, you will see the same thing. No changes of weight, also if the gyroscope is spinning with its axis of rotation in horizontal position.
All its weight is transferred to the contact point on the base of the gyroscope.
Sorry for believers in antigravity UFOs or such things.

Since the spinning wheel is now a gyroscope, it wants to remain in the same vertical plane. The experimenter is now effectively holding the end of a lever, which he lifts. The gyroscope wants to remain vertical, and is at the load end of a lever, so it takes less work to raise the wheel than lower the hand.
And I'm not sure, but if he split the wheel in two, and spun them in opposite directions, he'd also get rid of the torque that's causing him to rotate.

It's the gyroscopic effect that makes it so. This means : a force applied anywhere on the wheel  is experienced 90 degrees later. you can test this with a bicycle-wheel. You can hang it on a string attached on one side of the anxle. If the wheel spins fast enough it will stay up-right. A helicopter-rotor experiences this to. Say : the rotor is spinning clockwise. If the rotor is to be tilted forward, the initial force is appied to the left side of the rotor. SOunds strange, but it's true.

Why does the wheel feel lighter? Here's my explanation: it isn't, in reality, any lighter than when it isn't spinning. But it does require much more effort to hold it horizontally because, while it takes very little effort to simply suspend 40 pounds from one's hand (this happens in both cases), it would require a Herculean effort to supply sufficient ROTATIONAL force, also called torque, using only the small muscles in one's forearm - the whole thing is like seesaw centered at the man's wrist, and to hold it horizontally when not spinning, he would have to resist this tendency to rotate by supplying an equivalent amount of torque. But when spinning, a curious thing happens. In an idealized situation, all the man needs to do is supply the upward 40 pound force, without that torque required in the other case, to keep it from falling to the ground. This can also be seen in a gyroscope suspended from a string - since the string is flexible, it is virtually unable to supply any rotational force in the direction an unspun wheel would tend to rotate, but the spun gyroscope stays nearly horizontal even though the string really only supplies an upward tension force. Also, notice that in both the spun and unspun cases, torque does cause a rotation - towards the ground when unspun, and horizontal when spinning very fast - but the man in the video only attempts to resist this rotational tendency in the first case. Correct me if I'm wrong, people who are better in physics than I am, but I would expect that it would take the same torque to resist the rotation around a vertical axis in the second case as would be required to resist rotation about a horizontal axis in the first.

It's significantly easier to apply centrifugal force via motors then move them across an arm due to the laws of levers, specifically type two. This could also lock axises due to how centrifugal force increases the outwards force on one single axis. If you've ever played with a gyroscope toy and turned it, you'd be able to see the motion and speed lost as the axis shifts direction as well as the amount of effort it takes to change the axis so applicable to vehicles. An automatic driving mechanism could very well rely on a counterweight in the future especially with high capacity planes. helicopters use some of this energy in an essential way as their blades help to stabilize the plane BUT the helicopter moves due to the direction and adjustments of the blades forcing the air through in the same way a cap is screwed on a coke and a cork passes through a wine glass. Picture a projectile, vehicle or ship that is at one point powered by a motor with a fly wheel and projected from an arm on another axis and the tremendous amount of control on a significantly less amount of weight. The MASS is still their but the initial weight is altered due to the centripetal force pushing outwards equally in all directions. An apparatus like this in space could create artificial gravity in space.
Picture this applied to something with tremendous wieght that already needs a counterweight. A motor consistently spinning and adjusting the weight by editing the speed and keeping it in balance.

Because of the precession the axis of rotation resists changing angle. Which means the bar's angle doesn't change. when lifted it acts like a lever, with the fulcrum at the center of the precession. As the wheel goes up, it goes up at an angle along a spiral path. It is similar to pushing a cart up a ramp. If the angle of the ramp is low, the force required is low, but needs to be applied over a greater distance (time).

The forward motion caused by gyroscopic precession and the additional pushing force you apply with the left hand (just before lifting the spinning wheel with your right) is transferred to and assisting your right hand as you lift it.  The wheel weighs the same, but there is a larger amount of energy applied to the motion of the rod (when it is spinning).  Also, you no longer need to apply energy necessary for balancing this awkward weight in the first (non-spinning) lift.  The energy you would have used to balance the weight can now be applied to the singular motion of lifting it.  Therefore 2 additional forces and one "unspent" force are easing the second lift, making it seem lighter when ever the wheel is spinning.

Some really dopey suggestions in these comments. It has a mass of 19kg that will not change until part of the apparatus is discarded. This is NOT its weight. The weight is a resultant of the vector addition of all the forces acting on the apparatus. The guy says it feels lighter spinning than stationary. This can only be due to an upward force acting against the downward force (the weight of the apparatus) causing the resultant force downwards to be less than the weight of the apparatus. The man and spinning object does not lose mass, they lose weight because weight is a force whereas mass is not.
A comment said "it gains inertia" as it spins up. This is false. Inertia is measured by the kilogrammes as the inertia of an object is its mass and the spinning object neither gains or loses mass. It does however gain rotational momentum which is a multiplication of its mass and its rotational velocity. As its rotational velocity increases, so does its rotational momentum.

The reason it feels lighter is the rod is applying a torque on his arm due to the inertia of the fly wheel. When his wrist holds the rod steady and prevents it from twisting around in a circle, he essentially allows the flywheel to sort of "climb" upwards.

Basically think of it as: part of the energy it takes to prevent the bar from rotating around in a circle is going into helping you lift it upwards. Because the bar wasn't trying to rotate earlier when the wheel was stationary, you needed 100% lifting force.

After the wheel is spinning, you need 20% force to prevent twisting, and 80% to lift. This makes it feel lighter while lifting but you still put the energy in, just in a different way. On a scale, however, you would weigh the same.

In my opinion, if without gravity the precession will not occur; and the speed of precession depend on gravity force (would precession faster if the gravity were more  intense). Anything will not fall without gravity. Spinning things also fall. When a thing with axial stick spin, its collected rotation power send force to not only air around it; sending air contacting it to different directions.  It sends air up, down, left, right, and... It also send force to the axial stick. The portion of mass on the spinning downward side pulls down sending force on the axial rigid solid stick in the line to one's hand(s); but the opposite portion pulls up. Like when one swing a ball with rope, when the ball going down it pulls one's hand down; and when the ball going up it really has force on one's hand (the force pulling the hand upward). It should be because of rigidity of the stick makes the weight of the spinning wheel moving from its center to the hand(s). Maybe by something like shaking like a stick if one vibrates a tip of the stick up and down rapidly, the other tip will send force down and up hitting ground or a holding hand on the side of the other tip. I imagine so. So, It should be a bit shaking holding the axial stick; but the opposite forces happen in the same time with very high frequency, so that, it must be hard to feel.    When the spinning is very powerful, the pulling forces would be very strong, much stronger than gravity force like elephant and ant. So that, the feeling of the gravity doing something at the wheel point is like zero. Maybe, gravity force was also combined with the spinning force and make the feeling of the wheel weight at the hand point. The weight total is still the same, but the feeling of law of the lever is almost disappear. Rotation power going down because of gravity effect on the left side(going up). It feels easier because you lift it up along a longer path when you rotate it around yourself vs pushing it up straight up. It's like trying to get on top of a mountain in a straight line vs going along a serpentine road. The amount of energy you need to spend per unit of time is much smaller is the second case, so it takes longer to do but much easier, while in the first case you might not be "strong" enough to pull it off. The gyroscopic effect simply helps you to hold on a long shaft but really it's the same as tying it to a rope and spin it around till it's above your head.

So I watched the explanation video and this makes sense now. For those of you that don't understand quite yet... think of it this way. When you are holding the weight still (static), you have to not only hold the gravitational force up, but you must apply torque to counter balance the torque of the wheel toward the ground. When you spin the wheel at a few thousand RPM, you are introducing a very large kinetic energy, and we all know that kinetic energy DOES something! The kinetic energy of the wheel spinning creates torque, which replaces the force that your "torque" hand had to produce in order to keep the wheel from tilting toward the ground. Now, your body is only exerting force to hold the vertical gravitational force, giving the effect that the object is lighter. The object isn't lighter, you are just exerting less force to perform the same task because a machine took care of half the task for you ^_^

Actually it can be explained by newtons laws.  Essentially you are converting rotary energy into centerpoint repulsion.  Thus you shift the center of gravity of the object to its edges, which are in motion, which generates repulsion away from itself, which causes it to feel lighter.  This may reduce the energy neccesary for lift, however, the objects mass and weight stay the same.  
The same thing wiould happen if you oscillated it at a high enough frequency such that the speed and distance of rotary displacement equals the speed of what you have in the video.  

In Vector force terms, you are doing something which allows you to make it lighter feeling as well, using this "repulsion", you are rotating it in the direction of the spin of the wheel as you are lifting it, allowing the "repulsion" of the weight rotating to impart upward momentum. 

Heres where I will be proven correct:  Attempt to lift it without changing axial direction, so keeping it parrelel to the earth without rotating.  You will notice that the weight stays the same

Then lift it doing your rotating around your head.  You will notice the weight lessen, then return when you hold it above your head.

If doing the first experiment I suggested yields less weight, then you might want to investigate what the flywheel is made of and go from there.

Surely the ease of motion is due to the distribution of weight. When trying to lift it as a asymmetrical load you're wasting significant energy just offsetting the lean. When the gyroscopic action is in effect the weight is pressing down on your palm. This is similar to why it's harder to lift free weights at the gym than lift an equivalent weight at a machine, with a free weight there's compensation for the extra degrees of motion which wastes energy but engages more muscles not directly required for a more limited motion.

A flywheel is a spinning wheel or disc with a fixed axle so that rotation is only about one axis. Energy is stored in the rotor as kinetic energy, or more specifically, rotational energy:

E_k=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^2
Where:

ω is the angular velocity, and
 I  is the moment of inertia of the mass about the center of rotation. The moment of inertia is the measure of resistance to torque applied on a spinning object (i.e. the higher the moment of inertia, the slower it will spin when a given force is applied).
The moment of inertia for a solid cylinder is I = \frac{1}{2} mr^2,
for a thin-walled empty cylinder is I = m r^2,
and for a thick-walled empty cylinder is I = \frac{1}{2} m({r_\mathrm{external}}^2 + {r_\mathrm{internal}}^2) ,[6]
Where m denotes mass, and r denotes a radius.

When calculating with SI units, the standards would be for mass, kilograms; for radius, meters; and for angular velocity, radians per second. The resulting answer would be in joules.

The amount of energy that can safely be stored in the rotor depends on the point at which the rotor will warp or shatter. The hoop stress on the rotor is a major consideration in the design of a flywheel energy storage system.

 \sigma_t = \rho r^2 \omega^2 \ 
Where:

 \sigma_t  is the tensile stress on the rim of the cylinder
 \rho  is the density of the cylinder
 r  is the radius of the cylinder, and
 \omega  is the angular velocity of the cylinder.
This formula can also be simplified using specific tensile strength and tangent velocity:

 \frac{\sigma_t}{\rho} = v^2 
Where:

 \frac{\sigma_t}{\rho}  is the specific tensile strength of the material
 v  is the tangent velocity of the rim.

first point of interest.

1. all spinning masses generate a negative charged field that spins outwardly perpendicularly from the axis.

2. any mass with an electrical circuit of great current has an electromagnetic field expanding perpendicular to the direction of the currents flow.

3. any two like charged particles will push away from each other. force with which they push is directly proportionate to the mas and density of the (negative charge/electrical flow in circuit)

by spinning a large metallic mass you have created a gyroscopic electromagnet.

by allowing the the gyroscopic mass to travel in the path of it's own rotation while yet pinning the other end of the rod, you have created an anchoring axis.

while lifting the axis point upward you are aiding the expanding flow of the electric current, and the magnetic fields expanding from the axis of the gyroscope. in essence assisting the outward thrust against any negative charged particles.

Philosophy 101
When we use the word 'anti-gravity', what do we mean by that ? It is an overused term, particularly when gravity as a force is still not completely understood. Electromagnetic levitation produces a force greater than gravity, just like ionocraft do, or a helicopter working with the gasseous envelope of the Earths atmosphere to produce a force that can COUNTER gravity and work against it. It is not known if electric and magnetic forces have anything to do with gravity at all or even what gravity is made up of 'gravitons' or 'gravitonic waves' ? It is all STILL even in the 21st century only theory. We know gravity exists, some of its laws, but not what it actually IS...whether centrifugal or centripüetal forces can effect gravity as in gyroscopes or spinning tops is an intriguing question, perhaps answered by Prof. Laithwaite who hammered investigating this weird effect to bits, but, well...why does it seem lighter, is it lighter ? Fascinating questions...

The apparent weight loss is caused by the fact that when you lift the weight above your head you have to twist your body around slightly ...and it feels lighter.

What is happening is the downward energy is being dissapeted in the side muscles of the hips and upper legs and torso that you don't normally use when you just lift an object straight up.

Basically more muscles in the body are being used (each with less energy) so it "FEELS" lighter.

A few points:
1. You have supplied a large amount of energy into the spinning disk  from the driller.
2. Spinning disks are used as inertial storage even on satellites. They have energy in them
3. the torq is helping you when you rotate the disk on top of your head. If you rotate it in reverse, it will be against the torq and you might lose your head(Careful, it looks heavy).

My Conclusion, Its not anti gravity. Its inertial laws that works with it. As for the weight, the weighing scales show different weights based on the center of gravity. I am quite confident that the center of gravity is varying due to the body and disk motion. Its not a real change of weight.

I FIGURED IT OUT!
2 types of Gravity are cancelling the other out. 

The wheel creates a 0-state at it's 0-point/axis & negates natural gravity only in the direction of that the Centrifugal force is created. Again, this cancellation is only in one direction & still doesn't cancel out all gravity.

Everything outside the 0-point during the spin, ceases to have  everything else that moves ceases to be affected by gravity.

Or in otherwords, Perpetual/Momentary-Motion/Action cancels out Gravity....but only in a certain direction. It still requires energy & direction....so it isn't 100% efficient or passively counter to gravity.

Technically I can create an Anti-Gravity Engine...but only if I put 2 discs perpendicular to the other & try to spin them both upon a 0-point evenly & at the same time, with perfect timing.

Basically what I am describing is THE SOUL...which is impossible to produce through mundane means. :)

I know the calculation is much simple than you would expect:

T = d/dt (Iw) = mgr j for a perfectly horizontal spinning axis, I being moment of inertia, w being the angular velocity, T being the torque vector, g gravity, r the radius from the center of the rotating man to the flywheel, m mass, and j is the vertical unit vector. Thus the torque balancing equation is:

|| d/dt (Iw) ||= mgr     for perfectly horizontal axis constant w and constant rotating man speed.

Here is the real question.....How much of your energy is being used here?

This is like forcing a spinning 42 LB weight up a fixed a spiral  curve which emanates from a central point, getting progressively farther away from the plane of the earth as it revolves around the focal point. incline to reach a height over your head.

You are holding the focal point on the shaft, and taking a specific length of time and a specific amount of motion to get it up to a point. Note the distance the disk has to travel to get it over your head as opposed to just lifting it straight up over your head..  

The amount of time it takes  and the distance involved because of  (rotating it up) rather than lifting it straight up (which would be a shorter distance) but it actually takes the same energy to get it over your head, and that is the key here.   The gyro action of the spinning disk on a shaft gives you a focal point along the shaft  acting as a lever.

It's like you are actually levering up the 42 lb weight and spreading the energy exerted over a specific amount of time and space,. you are not actually lifting 42 lbs straight over your head instantly, It's more like you are lifting 10.5  lbs over your head, 4 times in an allotted (spread out) amount of time, and distance........and holding the accumulated weight (the 42lbs) there momentarily. 

Regardless of getting it up there the way you did, you are expending very nearly same amount of universal energy (maybe even more by doing that way)  from the source of the energy (your muscles) needed in order to accomplish the action, which is actually in line with the laws of physics. Time - space- and speed are all one fundamental conception. .

Force=Mass x Acceleration    (Don't forget the energy that was expended to start the disk spinning.)..

It feels lighter because you don't have to worry about balancing it.  You spend extra muscular effort keep it under control due to not being able to always lift it at the CG, and having the cg be dynamically unstable when the wheel is not spinning.  The spin takes a lot of the non-centerline torque factor out, the dynamically unstable balancing out, and the off-centerline CG problems out.  Lifting while spinning gives you a much better idea of the actual force required.
Think about trying to lift a 20 lb piece of wood that is 15 feet long, vs a 20 lb piece of dense metal that fits in the palm of your hand.  The extra effort expended compensating for unwieldiness is the difference.

It's not an anti-gravity wheel (as what the title suggests). It is simple flywheel. Just like a gyroscope, it resists angular variations due to the conservation of angular momentum. A real anti-gravity device is something that would repel gravity itself without using any other forces (i.e. magnetism, etc.). To achieve a negative gravity, the device must have a negative mass.

No antigravity here; the secret here is the leverage that the long handle provides.  The spinning flywheel makes the apparatus tip-proof as well as forcing the precession (where the flywheel travels in a big arc), so when the guy pushes up, the flywheel moves upwards over a long corkscrew path.  It's very much as if a person were pushing a heavy object up a long corkscrew-shaped incline: it wouldn't require much force because of the long path.  Basic mechanical advantage.

Rotational force produces kinetic energy in the wheel he is holding, he used that kinetic energy by giving it some direction, so with his hand holding it he moved his arm upwards, which told the kinetic energy inside the rotating wheel to go up, but we see him applying some force not just giving direction to the wheel and that's because there is another force (gravity) that's pulling that wheel towards ground, therefore he has to use some force to cancel the effect of gravity. Then he needed more kinetic energy to pick that wheel up above his head which he got by rotating the wheel for longer time and with more speed.
With that being said this technology is already in application in different fields. Space, electricity etc., although some minor things are in market but technological breakthrough applications are still under R&D.

Try this same experiment, except with a different flywheel.
Give it a much larger diameter while maintaining the same weight.
You'll find that it will produce considerably more gyroscopic force at the same RPM, so everything that you were demonstrating will become much easier to do.
You can actually reduce weight and make it larger for a better demonstration of force, but there's a point in which reduced weight will reduce spin-down time.
Current gyros are lighter and faster today because they use tungsten and alloys that can withstand much higher centrifugal forces than conventional steel.

I disagree with your explanation about the reason to 'why does it feel heavier'

You see, when you tried to lift it while the wheel wasn't spinning, you used only one arm, which was located around the center of gravity of the device, you didn't have to add more force to counter the torque.

On the other hand (same hand actually), you did have to balance the weight above your head. 
Because the weight is quite heave, it is very hard to balance it, especially with one hand.
You can see your whole body working an sort of shaking very fast to make the adjustments and keeping the weight balanced.

But when the wheel was spinning, it felt like someone was holding the other hand of the shaft, you didn't have to hold it at the center of gravity nor balance it.
I believe that this is one of the reasons that it felt much easier.

This is why training with free weights as more effective than using gym equipment that supposed to train the same muscles.

How is posiblety?

When you increase the spin of the wheel, you are adding and subtracting velocities at different parts of the wheel, relative to the observer. By rotating and revolving the wheel in the right direction, you increase the average kinetic energy of the object around the principal axis (of revolution).

Let u be the component velocity directed around the principal axis (of revolution) of

....the rod's end in the wheel's center.

Let v be the component velocity directed around the principal axis (of revolution) of

....a point mass on the disk, less that of the rod's end in the wheel's center.

As it turns out:
(u + v)^2 - u^2 > u^2 - (u - v)^2

Proof:
(u + v)^2 + (u - v)^2 > 2 * u^2
u^2 + 2uv + v^2 + u^2 - 2uv + v^2 > 2 * u^2
u^2 + v^2 + u^2 + v^2 > 2 * u^2
v^2 + v^2 > 0
2v^2 > 0

Essentially, what this means is that the average specific kinetic energy of the object's mass constituents is greater than (1/2)u^2, because the specific kinetic energy of the mass' constituents gained by rotation in the direction with the path of revolution exceeds the specific kinetic energy lost by rotation against the path of revolution by a maximum amount of 2v^2. This generates a torque on the rod different than implied by considering only the gravitational force on the rod.

Here's why the torque on the rod changes. During precession, the bottom part of the wheel moves faster than the top part of the wheel by an amount of 2v, and it has a specific kinetic energy which is greater by an amount of 4uv (not 4v^2), with respect to the principal axis (of revolution). As a result, the bottom of the wheel has a greater tendency than on the top of the wheel to remain in a straight path (i.e. it has greater momentum). However, as the rod is being pulled toward the fixed pivot, thus giving rise to a centripetal force, the unsymmetrical (fictitious) outward force by the wheel (observed in the rotating, non-inertial frame of reference) is in the inertial frame a torque on the rod, which then forces the wheel upward.

If you are trying to imagine how this could be applied to an object (UFO maybe) the theory would work if you had maybe.....a dozen opposed wheels. One wheel to counteract the other, so you would need an even number. However in my hypothesis, this would only render the wheels "weightless", not the whole aircraft. This object wouldn't cause any more lift needed to elevate the rest of the aircraft, only provide enough force to overcome it's own weight. Assuming you only need the wheels to fly, less aircraft, you would still need a propulsion system, otherwise your flight time would be considerably limited. Yet, still a fun little experiment.

It feels light because you can build momentum from the initial two handed lift in the dead-lift position.  When it is not spinning, all the weight is on one arm.

So if you plot your weight + the wheel over time in both scenarios, you'll see more force on the initial lift when the wheel is spinning which reduces the force needed later to get the weight overhead.  For a non-spinning weight, you can't build as much initial momentum.  If you were lifting a 40 lb soft sandbag, the weight would be even worse as you get it overhead.

If you rotate a hollow disk containing a very heavy liquid (sans the axle) with sufficient angular velocity, in the horizontal plane, then compress the fluid into the center of the disk, one will discover that the disk will rise above the ground. The greater the fluid density and angular velocity the faster the spinning disk will rise. The torque induced procession will be reduced to a point (as r is minimized) and one is left with a induced force opposite in direction to that of gravity. This is an antigravity engine folks - do the math.
Of course actually conducting this experiment requires a great deal of energy. Enjoy.

I think the biggest source of confusion is that people don't understand how moments work.

I'll try to lay it out.

The wheel weighs 19kg which is a downward force of 186N.
If you're trying to hold that bar at .7m from the wheel, you're going to have to apply 434N at the end of the bar (not the wheel end) to balance the downward force around your supporting hand (since the end of the bar is closer to your hand than the wheel, you have to apply more force [law of the lever]).

You then need to push up with about 620N to hold up the wheel, and also the force you're apply downward to balance it, which is a lot more than 186N.
When gyroscopic procession is occurring, you don't need to apply that balancing force, so you only need to support the system with 186N.

The mass DOES NOT CHANGE, but the force required to support it does, and that's why it feels lighter.
Wow! very nice topic! I always had this doubt! @Veritasium  thank you for clearing my doubt. :)
Thank you for kilograms, as soon as you mentioned a scale, I opened up a pounds to kilograms converter page.

As you raise the weight you are raising the center of mass by applying a force which will cause the scale to read a higher weight. Once the weight is at its highest point the scale will read 91Kg.
When the gyro is not spinning the bar is unstable and wants to tilt wildly requiring some muscle strength to stabilize it. During gyro rotation, the reason it feels lighter is because the lifting bar is stable along its axis and doesn't require any muscle to stabilize it. This makes more muscle available for lifting and makes it less strenuous.
